text: these are rare pictures from one of the
most dangerous places in Afghanistan the
government and the Taliban have been
fighting each other here for years but
now militants from so-called Islamic
state have entered the fray in recent
months they have captured large parts of
desorb district thousands of people have
been displaced by the fighting it is too
risky to go to the frontline and this is
as far as we can get this place just
outside the town is home to nearly 90%
of people who have fled desert and left
everything behind one room can shelter
two to three families the majority are
women and children who Mayra and her
sister-in-law are among them her husband
was one of the local leaders fighting
against the two militant groups just a
few weeks ago he was called my husband
was ambushed by is the port petrol over
his body and set him on fire when I
escaped to our house they set it on fire
everything was destroyed we ran away
with the children until we arrived to a
place where we felt safe and adding to
the volatile mix here our powerful local
warlords who frequently switch
allegiances share Mohammed's militia is
fighting both the Taliban and is he lost
a hand in the fighting and almost lost
his life in just three months we lost
more than 60 men from our village our
commanders asked for help from the
government we asked them to send
helicopter to evacuate our injured
people
but the local government needs help most
officials have fled toss up including
the governor there is no functional
government in Gaza everything is
paralyzed the only safe access to the
district now is by air Isis and Taliban
have checkpoints in about 50 different
locations the road leading to DARS up
stays at all
it used to be packed with cars taking
passengers in both directions now is and
the Taliban controlled key parts and no
one travels unless they absolutely have
to the grim reality of days off extends
beyond its borders if eyes militant sees
all of the district there were also the
control access to three key northern
provinces and more people could pay the
price of this increasingly complex war
Ferris Rahimi BBC News northern
Afghanistan
